references.R89SPE01USGP: Speich, S.M., and T.R. Wahl. 1989. Catalog of Washington seabird colonies. U.S. Fish Wildl. Sen. Biol. Rep. 88(6). 510 PP.
references.B19BEN01USGP: Bent, A. C. 1919. Life histories of North American diving birds. U.S. Natl. Mus. Bull. 107.
references.A11AIN01USGP: Ainley, David, D. A. Manuwal, Josh Adams and A. C. Thoresen. 2011. Cassin's Auklet (Ptychoramphus aleuticus), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/050
references.B87BRI01USGP: Briggs, K. T., W. B. Tyler, D. B. Lewis, and D. R. Carlson. 1987. Bird communities at sea off California: 1975-1983. Stud. Avian Biol. 11.
references.A79VER02USGP: Vermeer, K., R. A. Vermeer, K. R. Summers, and R. R. Billings. 1979. Numbers and habitat selection of Cassin's Auklets on Triangle Island, British Columbia. Auk 96:143-151.

habitat_description:
Ptychoramphus aleuticus comes ashore only to breed (Bent, 1919; Speich and Wahl, 1989). Nests are typically burrows in soil or in rock crevices (Thoresen, 1964; Manuwal, 1974; Vermeer et al., 1979; Vermeer and Lemon, 1986; Gaston, 1992; Adams et al., 2004; Lee et al., 2007; Lee et al., 2012). On treed islands, the species nests at the edge of the forest (Vermeer et al., 1979), burrowing in grass- or moss-covered ground. Nests are preferentially placed among areas that are bare or contain only short vegetation (Vermeer et al., 1979), though Vermeer and Lemon (1986) noted a majority of nests were under trees, stumps, or logs. Nests are typically along the periphery of islands, with the map presented by Vermeer and Lemon (1986) indicating the species remains within ~100 m of water. Nests are at elevations up to at least 150 m (Bent, 1919).

Cassin’s auklet forages at sea (Speich and Wahl, 1989; Adams et al., 2004; Lee et al., 2007; Boyd et al., 2008).

Neither nesting nor foraging occurs on the mainland, with the species typically remaining far offshore (Grinnell and Miller, 1944; Ainley et al., 2011), though Thoresen (1964) documented a colony on Castle Rock, roughly 1 kilometer from the mainland, near Crescent City, CA.
